_prev_prog_3.Description:
Anhydrous ammonia (CAS 7664-41-7) under pressure: 18,000 pounds in a closed-loop refrigeration process at pressure and temperature ranges of 30 to 154 psig and +24 to 160A?F in both vapor and liquid states (depending on process step).



Under a separate process, anhydrous ammonia (CAS 7664-41-7) liquefied under pressure: 300 pounds (Maximum amount) *may* be stored in an ASME-certified vessel; and is intended for use in a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system to control nitrogen oxides (NOX) emissions from a one Mega Watt natural gas fired turbine.  This process utilizes anhydrous ammonia in the capacity of a SCR for the Best Available Control Technology (BACT).  The SCR system reduces NOX emissions by injecting ammonia into the exhaust gas stream upstream of a catalyst matrix.  Nitrogen oxides, ammonia, and oxygen react on the surface of the catalyst to form nitrogen and water.  The catalyst is comprised of a noble metal and works within a high temperature range for proper operations (800A? F to 1100A?F).  As such, the control efficiency of the SCR system is reducing NOX emissions to about 90 percent.





The Level III Prevention Program applies to both processes.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
GILLS ONIONS

RISK AND PROCESS SAFETY MANAGEMENT PLAN 2104



1    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

    1.1   Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies.

    1.2   General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances.

    1.3   Summary of the General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-                 Specific Prevention Steps

    1.4   Summary of the Five-Year Accident History

    1.5   Summary of the Emergency Response Program

    1.6   Planned Changes to Improve Safety



1 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



Pursuant to the requirements of Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68.1 through 68.220 and Chapter 6.95, Article 2 of the California Health & Safety Code A?25531 through A?25543.3, this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is implemented as the California Accidental Release Prevention (Cal/ARP) Risk Management Plan under the Program Level 3 Designation.



The scope of this RMP is based on guidance from the City of Oxnard Fire Department Certified Unified Program Agency (Oxnard Fire/CUPA- the Agency with local authority for the RMP and Cal/ARP Programs), to ensure that contemporary issues are resolved and to incorporate state requirements.  The facility uses anhydrous ammonia (CAS 7664-41-7) in a closed-loop refrigeration process (18,000 lbs. maximum intended inventory) for temperature control of fresh onions.  Under a separate process, anhydrous ammonia is used in a Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) system (300 lbs. maximum).  The SCR is used to control nitrogen oxides (NOX) emissions from a one Mega Watt natural gas-fired turbine. The ammonia refrigeration system and SCR processes trigger the RMP requirements, both Federal and Cal/ARP. These processes were determined to be covered by Prevention Program III requirements.



At the time of this writing, the SCR Process was not being used; and the ammonia inventory in the SCR Receiver was negligible.  The facility however considers power backup essential to its business operations; this second Process will be

kept on standby.  



1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



The Gill's Onions policy is to protect its employees, environment, property, and the general public from harm that may occur as a result of its operations. To achieve this end, Gill's Onions strives to operate its facilities in compliance with applicable federal, state, and local safety, health, and environmental regulations.  With regard to the Ammonia Refrigeration and SCR Systems, the Accidental Release Prevention policy is to maintain compliance with the Risk and Process Safety Management Prevention Program elements.  The RMP/PSM programs are specifically designed and intended to prevent accidental releases; and to deal safely with emergencies if they do happen.



Gills Onions has adopted a Non-responding facility policy; Emergency Response pre-planning is coordinated with the Oxnard Fire/CUPA; and Facility Management.  Gills Onions has filed appropriate reports with the CUPA; measures have been taken to ensure the facility is included in the Community Emergency Plan.  The CUPA makes regular visits to the facility in accordance with California environmental regulations, which helps keep engine companies refreshed on Plant operations and layout.  The Gills Onions Emergency response policies are implemented to comply with the overall company policy of providing its workers with a safe workplace and minimizing risk to the public. Safety is the top priority.  Another priority is protection of the environment. Only after life, safety, environmental concerns are addressed will the focus shift to the secondary issues of property conservation and business recovery.



1.2 General Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances



Oxnard is located on the southern margin of the Oxnard Plain, approximately 5 miles inland from the Pacific Ocean and approximately 50 miles west of Los Angeles, California. The elevation of the facility is approximately 45 feet above sea

level. The nearest earthquake faults are the Pitas Point-Ventura Fault, approximately 8 miles to the northwest and the Anacapa (Dume) Fault, approximately 16 miles to the southwest located in the Pacific Ocean. The Anacapa (Dume) Fault produced a 5.9 magnitude earthquake in 1973.



The facility is zoned by the City of Oxnard as "M-2- Heavy Manufacturing", and is identified by the Ventura County Assessor's Office as Assessor's Parcel Number (APN) 201-0-301-030. The approximate center of the Site is located at latitude 34.191382? / longitude -119.1655751?.

It covers approximately 14 acres and is bounded on the north by Mountain View Avenue, on the east by  South Pacific Avenue and on the south by East Wooley Road. The Ventura County Railway Spur runs along the western property line which is used by other light industrial facilities to the west. The nearest major highway is State Route 1, the Pacific Coast Highway, approximately 0.5-miles to the west.



The nearest residential area, East Ash Street, is approximately 0.5-miles to the southwest. The next nearest residential area, La Puerta Street in La Colonia neighborhood, is approximately 0.65 miles to the northeast. The Oxnard Community Center Complex is approximately 1.25-miles to the west and the Center Point Mall is approximately 1.1 miles to the southwest. These are considered public receptors under the RMP regulation. The nearest designated environmental receptor is a Natural Preserve approximately 6 miles northwest of the facility. The Natural Preserve is located just north of McGrath State Beach on the Santa Clara River outlet to the Pacific Ocean.



The facility is designed to process and store onions. Processing includes washing, peeling, dicing, and packaging onions. The cold storage room, shipping dock, and receiving vestibule are designed to store onions at 34A?F by means of the ammonia refrigeration system.  The refrigeration system is designed to cool indoor air in processing rooms to approximately 4

o-day basis.

5.    The Refrigeration Plant Operator makes daily rounds using checklist and is on call.  

6.    The Plant has an established formal Inspection and Maintenance program.  

7.    A formal Injury and Illness Prevention & Training Program (IIPP) is established.  Personnel are trained according to their position and level of responsibility. 

8.    Employees are trained in hazard communication (Awareness level).

9.    Ammonia detectors

10.    Alarms: horns and beacon lights

11.    Emergency control panel linked to independent alarm systems controller to notify local emergency crews (i.e., fire department, police, etc.)

12.    Both the Refrigeration and SCR Systems are equipped with Fire Dept. Emergency Control Boxes

13.    Emergency shut-down switches

14.    Automatic cut-outs on refrigeration equipment

15.    Relief valves on both processes piped to header leading to ammonia a water (20,000 Ga.) diffuser tank

16.    PH monitors



1.3 No major changes in the refrigeration system



1.4 Summary of the Five-Year Accident History 



According to a review of Gills Onions history as of May 23, 2019 the Gills Onions facility in Oxnard  had no accidental ammonia releases that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage within the last five years



1.5 Emergency Response Program (ERP)



Gill's Onions has developed written emergency procedures to address elements that may be encountered during planning, responding or follow-up to an emergency at the facility. Application of the emergency procedures ensures compliance with OSHA Standard 29 CFR 1910.38 (Emergency Action Plans) within the emergency response element of the Risk Management Plan. The basic concept of Gill's Onions emergency procedures is to provide a comprehensive approach for managing emergencies. The four elements of this approach are prevention, preparedness, response, and recovery.



Th

5.    Gills Onions Internal Inspection Protocols



The programs above may result in recommendations ranging from capital improvements to routine maintenance of the plant.  Where appropriate Work Orders are established in parallel to identified needs.  Current planned changes to improve safety include recommendations as a result of the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation/Update performed May 23, 2019.  A written implementation schedule has been prepared.  Recommendations are scheduled for completion by December 16, 2019.
